15512122212.content:
You’ll never forget the day you first got Winona. You got her for your third birthday, and she was the best present you could ever ask for. She was the biggest plush toy you’d ever seen, around 2 feet tall, so she was almost as tall as you were back then! Of course, that was a long time ago. Now, you were seven, and the kangaroo plush fit snugly in your arms. She was still just as soft and comfy as ever, and cuddling with the toy reminded you of all the good times you’ve had in your life, and comforted you. You were a shy, weird kid, so most of the time Winona was your only friend. Still, you were content living with just your parents and Winona, like one big, happy family. Still, even that wasn’t meant to last forever...

Your memories of that one, fateful morning were blurry. Your parents went out just to buy some groceries. That usually takes them 15 minutes or so. But this time, an hour passed… and then another… and then another… and before you knew it, the sun was setting, and they still hadn’t come home. You stayed up all night waiting for them, and eventually, there was a knock on the door… but it wasn’t your parents, it was a police officer! He let you ride around in his police car, and even let Winona wear his police hat, so that was pretty cool, but you couldn’t shake the feeling that something was wrong. You kept trying to ask him where your parents were, but he kept dodging the question. Over the radio, though, you noticed him saying something about a ‘drunk driver’.

Eventually, he introduced you to a nice social worker lady that told you that your parents have been in an accident, and went up to heaven. You didn’t understand. Why would your parents just leave you here? She explained that they went to heaven without you because they wanted you to be happy here on earth, and that they’d be watching over you from now on. That answer didn’t satisfy you. You didn’t want them to watch over you, you wanted them to be with you. Still, you couldn’t think of any other arguments, so you just stayed silent from then on. You never cried, but you did hug Winona really, really hard. It seemed that, from now on, Winona was going to be the only friend you had left.

The nice social worker lady worked on your ‘case’ for a week or two. She told you that your parents had specified your grandmother as your guardian in their wills, and that the people in the courtroom had to decide whether she was capable. You liked the social worker lady, but you didn’t like the people in the courtroom. They were all so serious, and always talked about things you didn’t understand. Luckily, that whole process didn’t last long. Before you knew it, you were sitting in the back of the social worker’s car as she drove you to your grandmother’s house. The only possessions you were taking with you was an old lunchbox stuffed with toys and games, and of course, the big, stuffed kangaroo you held in your arms.

Luckily, this was the summer time, so you didn’t have to go to a new school right away; you could take a few month to process your grief and figure things. Your grandmother lived out in the countryside. It was kind of cool. There were horses and cows and stuff. Still, she didn’t have any cable or internet or anything, and you didn’t really have any friends nearby, so there wasn’t much to do. Your grandmother was nice, but she wasn’t very fun, and didn’t understand how to play any games. Thus, you spent most of your time lying around playing with your gameboy, and playing pretend games with Winona. Still, the lonelier you got, the more you wish Winona could talk, or move, or do anything. She was nice to snuggle with, but you just so desperately needed someone to talk to right now…

One night, you were sitting around in the living room playing Pokémon Yellow while your grandma silently knitting something, when suddenly she looked up and gasped. “Oh! Oliver! Look! A shooting star!” She stands up, more excited then you’ve ever seen her. You gaze out the window she was pointed towards, only to see a huge, beautiful star lighting up the entire sky as it flew past. “If you wish on a shooting star, it’ll come true!” She explained, and your heart skipped a beat. Maybe this was your chance to make things right! You consider asking for your parents to come back, but you figured the angels would be angry if you took somebody from heaven. No, no… you had another idea.

Winona couldn’t talk, or move, or anything, but she was always watching. She could always see what was going on around her. You’re sure she wanted to say something… but she couldn’t. She was just a toy. Still, you desperately wanted to hear whatever it was she had to say. She’d understand you… she’d finally give you a good explanation, so that things made sense. So, hugging your plush toy tightly against your chest, you looked up solemnly at the star. Dear shooting star… please, please let Winona talk, and move around, and play, so we can be friends for real, you whispered silently to the star.

Soon, the shooting star disappeared, and you noticed it was about your bedtime. Your grandma tucked you in, and kissed your forehead goodnight, leaving you alone with Winona. You stayed awake for an hour, just staring at the kangaroo, waiting for her to do something, convinced she’d spring to life at any moment. Still, she didn’t move, not giving even the faintest signs of life. You sighed as you gave up and rolled over in bed, deciding that this whole ‘shooting star’ business had just been a waste of time. Just a piece of dumb ol’ superstition. With that, you drifted to sleep, lonely as ever…

┄┄┄

In the middle of the night, in your sleep, you felt a pair of fuzzy, soft paws pull you into a hug. It felt like Winona was lying behind you, snuggling you against her unbelievably soft, comfy belly. Of course, that wasn’t possible. You were obviously just dreaming. Still, this had to be the comfiest dream you’ve ever had. With a sigh, you practically melt into the cozy arms, falling into the deepest, most relaxing slumber you’ve ever had…

┄┄┄

When you woke up, the feeling was gone. You rubbed the sleep from your eyes as you sat up in bed, seeing your room was completely empty. What a strange dream, you thought. Ever since what happened to your parents, you’ve been having terrible nightmares most nights… but this one was actually quite nice, although brief. Then again, that’s if it was a dream. You looked over to the chair you left Winona sitting in, and realized it was now completely empty. You raised a brow. Did grandma move her? You walk over to investigate, only to find a strange note left sitting on the chair;

Meet me in ol’ Palmer’s farmhouse ASAP :)

You stared at the note for a while. It was written in curvy handwriting you didn’t recognize, but beyond that, there weren’t any clues. You quickly rushed through your morning routine, your mind racing. Who wanted to meet you? Did somebody take Winona? Your grandma was the only person who could’ve done such a thing, but you could hear her in the kitchen right now. She couldn’t be expecting you to meet her anywhere. Could… could Winona have left that note herself? No, no… that was impossible, of course. But it was mighty coincidental this happened the morning after you made that wish. No matter how ridiculous it seemed, you just couldn’t shake the possibility.

Your grandmother smiled at you as you walked into the living room in a daze. “Good morning, sweetheart!” She says, looking up from her oven, the delicious smell of whatever she was cooking wafting through the entire house. “I was just about to make breakfast. Are you hungry?”

“N-no, maybe later,” you said, awkwardly. You figure it couldn’t hurt to ask, at least. “So, uh… did you leave that note in my room?”

“What note?” She said, sounding genuinely oblivious.

“... nevermind,” you said with a shaky voice, as you pick up your boots and quickly slide them on. “I think I’m going to go outside and play. Is that okay?” You call as you tie your shoes and throw on a light sweater.

“Of course! Be safe!” She replied, as you pushed open the front door. You shivered slightly as you stepped into the sunlight. You lived up north, so even in the summer, it could be quite chilly in the early mornings. That was the last thing on your mind at the moment, though. You wandered through the big, empty fields of the countryside for about ten minutes, with nobody in sight besides grazing farm animals, before finally coming across the farmhouse you were searching for. It was old and abandoned, and basically in the middle of nowhere, but it was always left unlocked, and it had been fun to explore during those boring, lonely summer days. Now, however, there was apparently someone inside… waiting for you. Could it really be Winona?

You sigh nervously as you push open the big, heavy wooden door, peeking slowly inside…
15512122212.title: The Worst Day Ever

155121222121.content:
“Hello? Is someone here?”

You peeked inside, to see the dusty old barn was completely empty, beside the big, plush kangaroo sitting in the middle. It… looked like Winona, but it was different somehow. Most notably, it was about four feet tall, almost twice Winona’s regular size! It was turned away from you, so you couldn’t tell if it was Winona or not, but as you moved closer, you thought you noticed… movement. Namely, the plush toy’s tail shifted just the tiniest little bit, as if moving on its own. You froze in place. Surely you must just be seeing things, right? It couldn’t be… “... W-Winona? Is that... you…?” You hazard a guess, as you creepy slowly closer.

The plush toy shifted again, as if startled. You watch in awe as the toy stands up on its own, standing at about your height. You try to come up with a rational explanation, but all those possibilities left your mind when the kangaroo turned around to reveal that, yes, this was definitely the Winona that you knew and loved. You jaw hung open as you watched Winona move around on her own, her tail swinging and her ears twitching just like a real kangaroo’s. More notably, she used to have the same expression locked permanently on her face; but now, defying all logic, her eyes and lips could move freely, which she demonstrated by giving you a big, warm smile.

An epiphany shook you to your core. You couldn’t deny it anymore. The wish you made… it worked! What grandma said was true! You had brought Winona to life! Unable to control yourself, you watched forward and practically leaped into the kangaroo’s arms. “Winona!” You cried, hugging the big, soft, comfy plush toy as tightly as you could.

“Oh, Oliver!” She smiled, wrapping her arms around you and returning the hug, cuddling you against her unbelievably soft, fluffy body.

“Y-you can talk! You can move!” You say, crying with excitement as you rested your head on the kangaroo’s shoulder, not wanting this hug to ever end.

“I know! Oliver, with your wish… I can do anything now!” She replied gleefully, obviously just as ecstatic about this as you were. “There’s so much I’ve been wanting to say!”

You look up at her with a sniffle, wiping a happy tear from your eye. “R-really?”

“Yes, Ollie! I might’ve never been able to move, but I’ve always been listening. Watching,” she explained, hugging you close. She frowned, as if about to address something serious. “I guess I wanted to say is that I’m… so, so sorry about what happened to your mom and dad. You’ve been very brave, but… no child should have to deal with something like that alone. I promise we can turn this summer around. We can have the best summer ever!”

“... yeah, we can, can’t we? The best summer ever!” You repeated, realizing just how true those words were. Even when she was just a regular toy, Winona was the funnest companions you’ve ever had. Now that she could talk and move around, it would be on a whole new level! As the two of you cuddled, you excitedly told her about all the games you could finally play together, and all the cool human technology you could show her, and all the places you could go to. All the while, she just nuzzled you with a smile, listening attentively, finding her excitement absolutely adorable. “Anyway, why are you so big now?”

“Oh, that’s why I wanted you to come to the farmhouse. I actually have another surprise for you…” She smirked, and another big smile dawned on your face. Another surprise? What could possible be better then this? To demonstrate, though, Winona had to stop hugging you, which disappointed you somewhat. “Stand back! Clear the way!” She said with a smile, and you walked over to the other side of the barn, watching her attentively, wondering what she could possibly be planning on showing you. Once you were out of harm’s way, she clenched her eyes shut as if concentrating… and to your shock, she started to grow right before your eyes!

Before you knew it, she was ten feet tall… then fifteen… then twenty! You worried for a moment that she might just break through the roof, be she stopped just short, reaching a size she was satisfied with. She was almost as big as this entire barn; about six times your height! “W-Winona! You’re huge!” You said, walking cautiously up to her and laying a hand on her fur. Her paws themselves were now bigger than your entire body!

“Yup! I can be as big or small as I want to be, now,” she said with a smile. Just her tiniest movement ended up knocking a hay bale off a nearby beam. “Whoops! Seems this might be a little too big, though. Hehe!”

“I don’t know…” You said, enraptured by the kangaroo’s incredible size. “I kind of like it.”

“How flattering! Well, be that as it may, I’d rather stick to a more manageable size,” she says. You stand back as she starts shrinking down again, this time deciding on a more reasonable 8 feet. She was still twice your size, though, with you being about waist-height. “There. Is this still big enough for ya?” You looked up at her, awed by her size. You’d always sort of wished Winona was bigger, but this was more than you could’ve ever imagined. You loved it! You nodded eagerly, a big smile on your face. She seemed flattered by your excitement, leaning back and patting her belly. “Heh, I’d hope! At this size, you’re small enough to fit in my pouch!”

“C-can I?” You said, practically hopping in excitement at the possibility. You used to use Winona’s pouch as a pocket for coins or whatever, though you always wished you were smalling enough to ride around inside her pouch yourself.

“Of course! Hop on in!” She smiled. You beamed with excitement as the kangaroo leaned forward and pulled open her pouch for you, seeing that you’d easily be able to fit inside. Without a moment’s hesitation, you crawled headfirst into her pouch. Her pouch was actually a lot deeper then you thought, and you ended up falling to the bottom, suddenly surrounded completely by her soft, comfy plush ‘skin’. This was better then you could’ve ever imagined! It was so delightfully warm inside her pouch, and you liked how it pressed you up against her big, round, pillowy belly. When you were lying still, it was the most comfortable place you’ve ever been — the only problem was that it was so tight, moving around was a little difficult. You could hear Winona giggling and laughing as you tried to pull yourself up to the entrance of her pouch. “Hehe! Don’t wriggle so much, I’m ticklish!”

“Sorry!” You laughed as you finally managed to poke your head out of her pouch, holding onto the edge with your hands, the rest of you tucked away inside the kangaroo’s huge pouch. You giggled in excitement as Winona started walking, easily carrying you around with her as she made her way out of the barn.

“Alright, Ollie. Hang on tight, now…” She said, and you gripped onto her pouch with all your might as she got ready to start really moving. Once you were ready, she started hopping, just like a real kangaroo would; but at Winona’s size, she hopped almost as fast as a car! You squealed and laughed in excitement as she hopped across the wide-open fields at 25 mph, the contents of her pouch getting jostled around with every hop. It was a little scary, but you’ve ridden roller coasters before, so it was nothing you couldn’t handle. In fact, it was a dream come true!

“Woohoo!” You cheered as she sped across the landscape, having more fun then you’ve had all summer. Luckily, you were out in the middle of nowhere, so there was nobody around to notice the giant kangaroo hopping through the fields. “Faster! Faster!” You egged her on, thrilled as she slowly worked her way up to 30 mph, then 35. Eventually, though, the kangaroo slowed to a crawl again. “Why’d you stop?”

“Phew… hold on… I have to catch my breath…” She said, leaning against a tree as she took a break, exhausted from all the hopping. You giggle, as you let go of the edge of her pouch, letting yourself sink back to the bottom. You just loved the warmth within her pouch, and the utter comfiness surrounding you on all sides. You almost never wanted to leave…

“Hey, Winona,” you ask, another idea intriguing. “Think I could just… live in here?”

“What do you mean?” She said, opening her pouch slightly so she could look down at you.

“It’s just so warm and comfy, I don’t think I ever want to leave!” You replied, smiling up at her, pushing playfully against the walls of the pouch. “I just need my gameboy, and some snacks sometimes, and I can just lay around in here forever…”

“Hehe! I’m glad you like my pouch so much… but don’t you think your grandmother might be a little upset?” She said. “After all the time she spent setting up your room and getting you settled in, why would you want to live somewhere else?” You sighed. You definitely liked Winona more then your grandmother, but… your grandmother was your guardian. She was the one who was taking care of you from now on. As much as you wanted her to be your new ‘mother’ or sorts, Winona was just your best friend, and you were satisfied with that. “Besides, I don’t want you in there all the time. Think of all the games we could be playing!” Well, you can’t argue with logic. In fact, at the moment, you felt in the mood for...
155121222121.title: The Best Summer Ever

choices: You come up with another idea
1551212221212.content:
Her pouch was definitely comfy, but another thought strikes you that fills you with even more excitement. Winona looks slightly surprised when you suddenly climb out from her pouch, practically leaping down to the ground below face-first. You stand up without skipping a beat, wiping the dirt off you with a big smile on your face. “Now that you can move, I can show you how to play video games!” You say, practically jumping with excitement. You’ve always wanted to share your favorite hobby with somebody, but none of the adults you’ve known understood it. “C’mon!” You say, excitedly running back to the house.

“Wait!” She said timidly. “We have to be careful bringing me around the house.”

“Why?” You asked, confused as you walked back to her.

“Ollie… we can’t let your grandmother know that I can move and talk now. We can’t let any grown-ups know,” she sighed, sadly.

“Well… why not?” You ask, bothered by the sad look on her face.

“Because it’s magic, and we can’t let them know magic is real,” she explained solemnly. “Grown-ups are… used to things being a certain way. If something happens that they don’t understand, they get scared.”

“You’re not scary, though!” You insist. “You’re, like, the least scary person ever!”

“I know, Ollie, but if they find out I can use magic, they might think I’m dangerous,” she replied. “They might try to take me away.”

You froze in place, your heart sinking in your chest. You felt your face going flush with fear. “T-take you away?” You gasp. “Forever?”

“Maybe,” she nodded softly with a frown.

You stood there, considering the possibility, only to have to turn away from the kangaroo as you paced back and forth nervously, your hands shivering. By the time you turned back to Winona, tears were streaming down your face, and your eyes were red from crying. “Noooo!” You sobbed, running up to Winona and hugging her for comfort. You couldn’t comprehend anybody taking her away from you, and the very thought was making you cry more then you have in years. “Why d-do people have to b-be such... bullies?”

Winona was shocked. Even when you lost your parents, you didn’t cry once… but now, for the first time in years, you were downright sobbing! She’d never seen you like this! She panicked when she realized what happened. After having lost everybody else you cared about, the thought of losing her too was enough to finally push you over the edge. “Oh, Ollie, don’t cry!” She insisted, wrapping her arms around you and hugging you close, pressing you against her soft belly, your tears wetting her ‘fur’. “Nobody’s ever going to take me away. I promise!”

You sniff, looking up at her. “Really?”

“I promise. I’ll always be there for you, Ollie. Always. You never have to worry about that,” she whispered reassuringly. Eventually, the kangaroo’s big, comfy hug calmed you down. “Now why don’t you show me your… what’s it called? Game Man?”

“Hehehe…” You giggled softly, wiping the tears from your cheeks with your sleeves. “It’s called a Game Boy, you big ol’ dummy...”

“‘Dummy’? Now look who’s being a bully!” She laughs.

You looked up at her, a devious look suddenly dawning on your face. “Heh. Yeah, I’m a bully,” you smile, “and I’m gonna getcha!” Before she could react, you playfully ‘tackled’ the massive kangaroo, and she pretended to fall down on her back in response, with you landing on top of her belly.

“Noooo!” She laughed as the two of you playfully wrestled in the dirt. “Help, somebody! I’m being bullied!” She was twice as big, and thus twice as tall as you were, but you weren’t afraid to fight dirty! Before she could roll you off of her, you reached down and started furiously ticking her sides, causing the kangaroo to giggle and squeal uncontrollably. “Hahaha! No, have mercy! I’m too ticklish!” Your playfight continued like this for a while, until you both finally wound down, giggling and exhausting.

“Hehehe…” She giggled as you laid down on her comfy, bed-like belly, too worn out to continue wrestling. She lifts you up by your sides, and easily sets you down on the ground in front of her as she sits up. “Alright, alright. I’m going to go back to my normal size now, okay? That way you can bring me inside without your grandmother noticing anything strange.”

“Okay...” You say, a little saddened by the fact she had to return to normal, even if it was only for a few moments. You watched as the 8-foot tall kangaroo started quickly shrinking to a fraction of her size. Eventually, she returned to her normal, 2-foot tall self. She went limp, like a toy, and went back to that exact same facial expression that used to be locked on her face, though there was visibly more cognizance behind her beady eyes, if that made any sense. “Whoa.” You said, picking her up. Her ‘act’ was so convincing, she looked just like she did when she was just a toy! This would surely convince anybody!

Feeling better, you start making you way back to your grandmother’s house. You shivered in the cold, wishing for a moment that you were inside Winona’s pouch again, but you tried to focus on the task at hand. Your grandmother smiled when you walked in and quickly kicked off your boots. “Oh, Oliver! I was wondering when you’d be back,” she greeted. “Did you have fun out there?”

“Yep!” You cry over your shoulder as you rush back to your room. “But, uh, I’m still not hungry, though, so… later!” You grandmother is a little confused as she hears you quickly slam your door behind you. You were acting awfully strange today. Perhaps you were just missing your parents? She resolves to come up with a nice surprise for you, just to make you feel better.

Meanwhile, you lock the door and set Winona down on your bed. “Okay, you can grow again now.” With that, she starts growing again, until you were about the same height at four feet tall. She stretches, glad she didn’t have to fake that same old smile any more.

“Mm! That’s better,” she said. “Now, what game did you want me to play, again?”

She watched as you dug under your bed, and excitedly pulled out your Game Boy, holding it up in front of her. “Pokemon!”

“... I’m sorry, I’m not familiar,” she blushed.

“Hehe! That’s okay, I’ll show you!” You said as you sat on the bed beside her, booting up Pokemon Yellow and handing the console to the plush kangaroo, who gently took it in her ‘hands’, curiously analyzing it.

“Oh, dear. This won’t be a difficult game, will it? My paws are a little… uncoordinated,” she frowned as she experimented with the device, “and slightly too big for these buttons.”

“No. I already beat the game, so you can just do whatever you want,” you smile, looking over her shoulder, watching her screen as she reached the main menu. “Press the A button.”

She selects ‘Continue’, and a few moments later, the game started up proper. Your character was currently hanging around one of the major cities, after you’ve already beaten the elite four. She curiously pressed buttons, until she realized she could move around your character. “Oh. Is this me?”

“Yep, you’re the human boy,” you point.

“Oh, like you! Hehe!” She giggled, her long, thick tail wagging behind her. “What’s this thing following me?”

“That’s Pikachu. It’s a Pokemon,” you say, and she stares at you, uncomprehending. “They're sort of like magical, super smart animals,” you sheepishly explain.

“Like me! Oh, I like this game already!” She smiled, seeming more excited now. You try patiently to walk her how to play the game, though she didn’t really seem to ‘get’ it. She definitely had fun just wandering around doing her own thing, though, even if she didn’t make any progress. Her paw pads were indeed a bit too big for the buttons, with her occasionally walking into walls and choosing the wrong options, but she didn’t seem to mind. She almost looked fascinated by the technology, despite how simple it was.

Eventually, just as she started getting bored with the game...
